(Courtest Tri-City ValleyCats) Noteworthy 1 / 1 Back to Gallery Astros choose Rogers to manage ValleyCats
The Houston Astros announced their minor-league field staffs for the 2016 season and have named Lamarr Rogers the next Tri-City ValleyCats manager.
Rogers, who managed rookie-level Greeneville last season, takes over for former ValleyCats manager Ed Romero . Romero managed Tri-City for three seasons and is no longer with the Astros' organization.
Rogers guided Greeneville to its first Appalachian League title in 11 years last season. It will be his second year with the Astros' organization.
Russ Steinhorn returns to the club for his fourth season as hitting coach and Ace Adams will join the ValleyCats as their new pitching coach. Adams was pitching coach for the Triple-A Fresno Grizzlies in 2015.
Chris Holt , Tri-City's pitching coach for the past two seasons, will fill that role for Greeneville in 2016.
Skiing: Lindsey Vonn says she feels "awesome" after resuming ski training free of pain, 10 weeks after fracturing a bone in her left ankle. The four-time overall World Cup champion made eight practice runs on a glacier on Thursday, without her ankle showing any reaction. Despite a lack of preparation, Vonn hasn't ruled out a start in Saturday's season-opening World Cup giant slalom in Soelden, Austria, if she feels "comfortable and confident."
College basketball: Louisville men's basketball coach Rick Pitino vows he "will not resign and let you down" as investigations continue into an escort's book allegations that former Cardinals staffer Andre McGee hired her and other dancers to strip and have sex with recruits and players. In a season preview Thursday on his website, the Hall of Fame coach apologized to fans for having to "endure the pain" of allegations by Katina Powell that McGee paid strippers to perform 22 shows from 2010-14 at the players' dormitory. Pitino, 63, has denied knowledge of the activities described in Powell's book.
